title: How to Crochet a Swirl Scarf

methods.name:
Method One: Simple Swirl Scarf[1]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Tie the yarn to the hook.
steps.description: Attach the yarn to the crochet hook using a standard slipknot. Note that most yarns will work well with this pattern. Heavier yarns will form thicker spirals, while lighter yarns will have a looser, more delicate appearance. If necessary, please see the "Tips" section for instructions on how to make a slipknot.

steps.headline: Work a foundation chain.
steps.description: From the loop on your hook, work a series of chain stitches to form the foundation row of your scarf. Continue chaining until the length reaches the length you desire for your scarf. As a general rule, 180 chains will work well for an adult-size scarf and 90 chains will work well for a child-size scarf. If you need further instruction on making chain stitches, please see the "Tips" section.

steps.headline: Double crochet in the second chain.
steps.description: Work one double crochet into the second chain currently from the hook. This is the start of your first working row. See the "Tips" section if you need help with the double crochet stitch.

steps.headline: Work across the row with a series of double crochet.
steps.description: Work one double crochet into the next chain, then two double crochet in the chain after that. Repeat this pattern across the entire chain. When you reach the end of the chain, you've completed your first row. Note that the row can end on either a set of one double crochet or two double crochet, depending on how many chains are in your foundation row. Both options are acceptable.

steps.headline: Double crochet twice in each stitch.
steps.description: For the second row, work two double crochet in each double crochet of the previous row. Continue until you reach the end of the row.

steps.headline: Repeat to desired width.
steps.description: For each consecutive row, follow the technique used to complete the second row. Work as many rows as needed to achieve the scarf width you desire. You can make the scarf as thin or wide as you wish, but a total of three to six rows will usually suffice.

steps.headline: Fasten off the yarn.
steps.description: When you reach the final stitch of the final row, cut the yarn, leaving a 4-inch (10-cm) tail. Pull this tail through the loop on your hook to fasten off the work. Weave the tails at both ends into the back side stitching of the scarf. The completion of this step completes the project.

methods.name:
Method Two: Granny Stitch Swirl Scarf[2]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Work a foundation chain.
steps.description: Attach the yarn to the crochet hook using a slipknot, then work a foundation row of chain stitches until the scarf reaches your desired length. The total number of chain stitches in your foundation must be a multiple of three. For a child's scarf, 90 chains will work well. For an adult's scarf 180 chains will work well. If you need help making a slipknot or chain stitch, please consult the "Tips" section of this article.

steps.headline: Double crochet twice into the third chain.
steps.description: Work two double crochet into the third chain currently from the hook. When counting chains, do not count the loop already on your hook. See the "Tips" section for more information on making the double crochet stitch.

steps.headline: Double crochet three times into every third chain.
steps.description: Skip two chains, then double crochet three times into the chain after that. Repeat this pattern across the entire row. If done correctly, you should have worked three double crochets into the final chain of your foundation row.

steps.headline: Work back down the other side.
steps.description: Chain three at the end of the row, then work three double crochets into each chain-two space you created during your first pass. Once you reach the beginning of the row again, slip stitch once into the top of your original chain-three. This completes the first full row. See the “Tips” section if you need instruction on creating slip stitches.

steps.headline: Double crochet and chain stitch across the second row.
steps.description:
Chain three at the start of the row. Work a series of double crochets into each space of the previous row. For each space:
Work three double crochets. Chain three. Work three double crochets into the same space. Repeat this pattern all the way down the row. Work this same pattern in the corner of the first row, as well.

steps.headline: Work back down the other side.
steps.description: Once you reach the end of the row, double back by working the same pattern into each space just created by your first pass through the second row. Continue back down the row in this manner, but do not work this pattern into the last space of the row.

steps.headline: Double crochet at the end of the second row.
steps.description: In the last space of the row, work three double crochets. Chain three, then work two double crochets into the same space. Note that your initial chain-three of this second row counts as a double crochet stitch, which is why you should only make two double crochets at the end instead of the three used in every other space. After working these stitches, slip stitch into the top of the chain-three made at the beginning of your second row.

steps.headline: Double crochet and chain stitch across the third row.
steps.description:
Chain three at the beginning of the row, then work an alternating series of double crochet into each chain-three space of your previous row. In the first space:
Work three double crochets. Chain three. Work three double crochets into the same space. In the second space:
Work three double crochets. Alternate back and forth between these two patterns across the entire row.

steps.headline: Reverse back down the third row.
steps.description: Once you reach the end of the row, repeat the same alternating pattern, working back across the stitches you just completed until you return to the beginning of the third row.

steps.headline: Slip stitch once more.
steps.description: Once you reach the end of the row, slip stitch into the original chain-three at the start of the third row. This action completes the third and final row of the scarf.

steps.headline: Fasten off.
steps.description: Cut the yarn, leaving a 4-inch (10-cm) tail. Pull this tail through the loop on your hook to fasten it off. Weave this tail and the tail at the start of the scarf into the back of your stitches. This step completes the project.

methods.name:
Method Three: Triple Crochet Swirl Scarf[3]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Create a foundation chain.
steps.description: Attach the yarn to your crochet hook, then work a foundation row of chain stitches that roughly matches your desired scarf length. For an adult's scarf, work a foundation of 170 chain stitches. For a child's scarf, work a foundation of 80 to 90 chain stitches. Use a slipknot to attach the yarn to your crochet hook. For further instruction on making slip knots and chain stitches, please see the "Tips" section of this article.

steps.headline: Single crochet across the first row.
steps.description: Single crochet once into the second chain from your hook, then single crochet once in each chain after that. Continue along in this manner until you reach the end of the row. See the “Tips” section if you need help with the single crochet stitch. At the end of the row, chain three. This chain is referred to as a "turning chain," and it allows you to set the height of the next row. Turn the work over before moving onto the next row.

steps.headline: Double crochet across the second row.
steps.description:
Double crochet into the stitch at the base of the turning chain. Then, double crochet once into the next stitch and twice into the stitch after that. For the remainder of the row, follow this pattern:
Double crochet once into the next stitch. Double crochet twice into the stitch after that. See the “Tips” section if you need further instruction on the double crochet stitch. Once you reach the end of the row, chain four to complete another turning chain. Turn the work over before continuing.

steps.headline: Triple (treble) crochet across the third row.
steps.description:
Triple crochet once into the stitch at the base of the turning chain. Then, triple crochet once into the next stitch and twice into the stitch after that. Repeat the same pattern across the entire row:
Triple crochet once in the next stitch. Triple crochet twice into the stitch after that. For further instruction on the triple crochet stitch, please see the "Tips" section of this article. At the end of the row, work a turning chain of five chain stitches. Turn the work over before continuing to the next row.

steps.headline: Double treble crochet across the fourth row.
steps.description:
Double treble crochet into the stitch at the base of the turning chain. After that, double treble crochet once into the next stitch and twice into the stitch after that. For the remainder of the row, follow the same pattern:
Double treble crochet once into the next stitch. Double treble crochet twice into the stitch after that. Please see the "Tips" section for additional instruction on the double treble crochet. Chain one when you reach the end of the row and turn before continuing.

steps.headline: Single crochet across the fifth row.
steps.description: Single crochet once into the stitch at the base of your turning chain. Single crochet twice into each stitch until you reach the end of the row. This is the final row, so there is no need to work a turning chain or to turn the work.

steps.headline: Fasten off the yarn.
steps.description: Cut the yarn, leaving a tail measuring at least 4 inches (10 cm) long. Pull this tail through the loop on your hook to fasten off the work. Weave this tail and the tail at the start of your work into the stitches along the end of the scarf. The completion of this step completes the overall project.
